I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
programmatic approach for the Third Capital Market Development Program,1 and (ii) proposed 
policy-based loans to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for subprogram 1 of the Third Capital 
Market Development Program. The report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for 
Supporting the Third Capital Market Development Program, and if the Board approves the 
proposed loans, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the TA. 
 
2.   The proposed program will support demand- and supply-side measures to broaden and 
deepen the financial system in Pakistan and ground it in a strong legal and regulatory framework 
in line with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) country partnership strategy, 2015–2019 and 
country operations business plan, 2020–2022 for Pakistan.2 It also fits in the framework of the 
$6 billion International Monetary Fund (IMF) Extended Fund Facility (EFF) program approved on 
3 July 2019 to facilitate improved macroeconomic management.3 The EFF program includes 
recommendations relating to finance sector reforms that focus on deepening access to finance, 
implementing a sound debt management strategy, and supporting private sector development. 
The proposed program contributes to EFF implementation and sustainability since it develops 
alternative sources of access to finance (i.e., capital markets), supports sound debt management 
through government bond market development, and facilitates private sector investment by 
mobilizing financial resources. The program, structured as two subprograms, will facilitate the 
design  and  implementation  of  necessary  reforms  to  create  an  enabling  environment  for 
competitive  capital markets. The programmatic approach will chronologically sequence the 
reforms in a multiyear framework (2019–2022) and provide for flexibility to incorporate changes 
where warranted. Even with the country’s evolving economic situation, the program’s design is 
robust because of its emphasis on the capital market enabling environment. Programmatic budget 
support will finance two subprograms, each designated as a fully front-loaded, single-tranche 
intervention to be implemented during 2019–2022. The attached TA will assist in implementing 
the program. 
 
II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
3.  A central objective of the government’s economic development strategy, as reflected in 
Vision 2025,4 is to elevate Pakistan’s status from a lower middle-income country to an upper 
middle-income one by 2025. The government has targeted the generation of job opportunities 
and enhanced income levels as top priorities. Achieving the objective of Vision 2025 will require 
substantial private and public investments to accelerate economic growth. Economic growth has 
been largely driven by public and private consumption, with very low levels of domestic savings 
and investment. At 15% of gross domestic product (GDP), Pakistan’s investment rate in 2020 is 
almost half of the South Asian average of 30% of GDP. Crowding out of private investment also 
occurs because of excessive government borrowing from banks to finance the deficit. Private

investment is less than 10% of GDP. Similarly, the domestic savings rate declined from 17.4% of 
GDP in 1990 to 5.2% of GDP in 2020; this is significantly lower than the rate of its regional peers 
in 2020: 28.0% in India, 25.0% in Bangladesh%, and 21.0% in Sri Lanka.5 Underdeveloped capital 
markets have contributed to the ineffective mobilization of savings. Consequently, the savings 
gap has led to a persistently high fiscal deficit that makes the economy dependent on volatile 
foreign capital. 
 
4.  Pakistan’s vulnerability may increase as the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) decelerated 
economic growth to –0.38% in fiscal year (FY) 20206 and inflows from exports and remittances 
were adversely impacted. Market capitalization as a percentage of GDP at the Pakistan Stock 
Exchange (PSX) declined from 16% of GDP on 1 March 2020 to 15% as of mid-August 2020. A 
steeper decline at the PSX has been prevented by a series of State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) policy 
rate cuts since mid-March 2020 that lowered the policy rate by 6.25% to 7.00% and the borrowing 
costs for firms. At the same time, Pakistan’s access to global financial markets has become more 
expensive because of an increase in the credit default spread since February 2020.7 As a result, 
developing robust and competitive domestic capital markets is even more critical and is an 
indispensable tool for mobilizing private investment and minimizing such external shocks. The 
program will aid the COVID-19 recovery phase through subprogram 1 reforms, such as enhanced 
access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through a dedicated capital 
market platform and mobilization of savings by onboarding new retail investors through simplified 
know-your-customer (KYC) procedures with biometric verification. The government has become 
increasingly aware of the need to institute appropriate reforms so that the capital markets can 
enhance intermediate savings and investments to drive sustainable economic growth. 
 
5.  ADB’s Strategy 2030 prioritizes developing the finance sector and capital markets to 
support sustainable economic development by creating an enabling environment for private 
investment.8 The program will not only support private sector expansion but also contribute to the 
operational priorities of (i) strengthening governance and institutional capacity through specific 
institutional strengthening reforms and (ii) accelerating progress in gender equality through 
reforms that enhance the participation of female investors. Facilitation of private sector investment 
was part of the country partnership strategy, 2015–2019 and is also a key area under the country 
partnership strategy, 2020–2024 (footnote 2). 
 
6.  Predominantly bank-based finance sector.9 Pakistan’s finance sector is predominantly 
a bank-based system that does not effectively play its intermediation role. As of April 2020, bank 
assets  accounted  for  almost  70%  of  the  country’s  total  financial  assets,  national  saving 
instruments and government bonds accounted for 25% of total financial assets, and the equity 
market contributed less than 5%. In comparison, bank assets accounted for 62% of GDP in 
Bangladesh, 81% in India, and 70% in Sri Lanka, while equity market assets accounted for 12% 
of GDP in Bangladesh, 14% in India, and 22% in Sri Lanka. Banks in Pakistan mainly offer short 
maturity  loans  and  are not  in  a strong  prudential  position  to  offer  long-term  financing  for 
infrastructure projects.

7.   Underdeveloped capital markets. Pakistan’s capital markets play a limited role in 
financial intermediation and resource mobilization. The PSX lacks depth in terms of the number 
of investors and the number of companies raising capital. Fewer than 250,000 individual investors 
(less than 0.1% of the population) have a stock investing account. The absence of a centralized 
KYC procedure and cumbersome customer onboarding requirements impede the participation of 
new investors in the capital markets. During 2015–2019, only 25 companies raised capital at the 
PSX, while private equity and venture capital capital-raising activity was four times higher. Market 
capitalization of the PSX accounted for only about 13% of the country’s GDP in mid-April 2020, 
regressing from 30% of GDP in May 2017. With 543 listed companies and $42 billion market 
capitalization, the PSX is below most of its regional peers in terms of market capitalization as a 
percentage of GDP (12% in Bangladesh, 21% in Sri Lanka, and 41% in India) in 2020. On 
average, 2.7 brokerage firms have defaulted per year since 2000, which adversely impacted 
market confidence. Rules to be listed on the PSX main board and the SME board, which was 
created to encourage start-ups, are restrictive. In addition, the SME board requires companies to 
have a 5-year history and be profitable for more than 2 years. As a result, no company has listed 
on the PSX’s SME board despite the country’s growing technology start-up ecosystem. The depth 
and breadth of the capital markets have also been restricted since many state-owned enterprises 
(SOEs) have not been listed on the PSX. As a result, SOEs also miss out on the benefits from 
efficiency improvements through the discipline of stock market listing. Sophisticated products 
such as options and derivatives are not available in the capital markets. 
 
8.  Constrained bond market development. Pakistan’s bond market (34% of GDP as of 
April 2020) is almost completely dominated by government borrowing. The government bond 
market is primarily short dated with an average debt maturity of 1.7 years. It does not fulfill its role 
as a benchmark pricing reference because of ad hoc government debt management practices 
arising from the absence of a professional debt management office (DMO). The operating 
framework of the government bond market system does not promote competitive bidding. 
Auctioning of government securities is not based on market prices and hampers the formulation 
of a credible government yield curve and a liquid bond market. Although auctions are conducted 
based on a preannounced auction calendar, the government decides the cut-off yield for the debt 
rather than accepting a market-determined yield for the announced volume. When the market 
asks for a price higher than what the government is willing to offer, the bids are frequently rejected. 
The price-driven approach has deep implications for Pakistan’s capital markets. It has restricted 
the volume and liquidity of longer-tenor government bonds, and yields do not then reflect true 
market conditions, which hinders the process of establishing a credible benchmark for medium- 
to long-term financing rates. This undermines the credibility of the primary market, as does the 
rejection of auction bids. The government bond market also does not offer sovereign sukuks 
(Islamic bonds) to cater to the liquidity management requirements of Islamic banks. 
 
9.  The nascent corporate bond market accounted for 2.2% of GDP as of April 2020 compared 
with 1.0% in Bangladesh, 1.0% in Sri Lanka, and 16.0% in India. The absence of an effective 
government bond market yield curve impedes the appropriate pricing of corporate bonds, and 
corporate bond issuances are therefore less attractive to issuers and investors. Tax distortions, 
such as a complex and uneven tax regime that disadvantages nonresident companies from 
investing in bonds, hinder bond market activity. On the demand side, major institutional investors 
(such as pension funds and insurance companies) have a limited role in financing government 
bonds and corporate bonds since these investors prefer National Savings Scheme instruments.10 
 
10 National Savings Scheme instruments, administered by the Central Directorate of National Savings, are attractive 
since these instruments are government backed and offer higher returns than equivalent money market instruments,

4 
The  participation  of  investors  across  the  maturity  spectrum  is  critical  to  support  market 
development. A diverse investor base also lowers the debt cost and volatility in market yields. 
 
10.  Limited coordination between the regulators. Reform opportunities begin with the 
regulators: the Securities and Exchange Commission of Pakistan (SECP), the SBP, and the DMO 
at the Ministry of Finance (MOF). The SECP acts as the company registrar and apex regulator 
for nonbank financial markets, including capital markets. The SBP, the central bank, regulates 
the banking industry. The DMO handles debt management at the MOF. A national strategic plan 
for capital market development is absent and an institutionalized forum for key agencies to 
coordinate their efforts does not exist. Financial stability is compromised because of limited policy 
coordination and joint supervision of the financial system by the key regulators. Gaps persist 
between regulators and risks may build across the financial system with no overarching oversight. 
 
11.  Persistent weakness in governance structures. The SECP’s operational and financial 
efficiency is constrained in terms of the unclear appointment process, siloed operations where 
commissioners are responsible only for their designated areas rather than acting as a collegiate 
body, and limited clarity in the policy board’s role. The SECP’s market surveillance system needs 
to be upgraded to ensure effective market monitoring. Its enforcement effectiveness is also 
challenged by the absence of a dedicated capital market tribunal. The court system does not have 
the competence to deliberate on securities cases, and the pace of resolving securities cases 
pending in the court system is also slow. 
 
12.  Similarly, the DMO under the MOF faces structural capacity issues and does not function 
as a properly empowered treasury operation that develops and implements a consolidated 
administrative framework for debt management. The DMO merely collates information and acts 
as a conduit to government securities auctions. All decisions on terms, tenor, and structure of 
debt are made on a fragmented basis across the MOF. The DMO also does not possess a 
centralized database for effective cash management and planning. This exposes the government 
to a risk of default in the case of any volatility in demand in the auctions for government bonds.11 
 
13.  In addition, the ability of the country’s Audit Oversight Board (AOB), which critically 
oversees audit firm quality in Pakistan and therefore contributes to market transparency, to 
effectively regulate the auditing profession is constrained in terms of its board composition 
eligibility criteria, its regulatory powers, and having a stable funding source. The AOB has weak 
eligibility criteria for former audit practitioners to serve as members of the AOB governing body, it 
lacks a legal mandate to conduct direct inspections of audit firms unconditionally, and it lacks a 
stable  source  of  funding  from  the  government  to  effectively  execute  its  powers  and 
responsibilities. Shareholders and investors rely on audited financial statements of companies to 
make informed decisions and therefore trust that only an audit firm with a satisfactory quality 
rating can review companies’ financial statements.

to anchor the program to the design of a long-term national capital market master plan. The

B.  Policy Reform and ADB’s Value Addition 
 
15.  ADB  has  been  engaging  with  Pakistan  since  the  1990s  and  has  been  the  lead 
development partner in the capital markets area. ADB  has supported the development of 
Pakistan’s financial markets through three initiatives over the past two decades. From 1997 to 
2002, support was mainly provided through a $250 million policy-based loan for the Capital Market 
Development Program to support the adoption of fundamental reforms.12 This program primarily 
contributed to the establishment of the SECP and the transition to a new regulatory regime. From 
2002 to 2007, support was provided through a $260 million policy-based loan for the Financial 
(Nonbank) Markets and Governance Program.13 The objective was to strengthen the pension, 
insurance, and savings systems, as well as strengthen the SECP’s regulatory regime in the 
nonbank  subsector. From  2007 to 2011, a $400 million policy-based loan  for the Second 
Generation of Capital Market Reform Program primarily supported developing an enabling 
environment for voluntary private pensions, adopting a professional certification regime, and 
implementing a self-regulatory organization model at the stock exchanges.14 Since 2011, ADB 
has continued engagement in the finance sector through a public sector enterprises reform 
program; the development of inclusive insurance markets in micro, small, and medium-sized 
enterprises; and disaster risk financing.15 
 
16.  The Capital Market Development Program was successfully implemented with concrete 
results; subsequent financial markets program and the second generation program mentioned 
above were partly successful. The proposed program will build on lessons from the Independent 
Evaluation Department’s special evaluation study and the completion reports of the three previous 
programs. The program’s effectiveness will be facilitated by (i) a limited number of impactful policy 
actions to monitor program compliance effectively (previous programs had too many actions and 
too broad a focus); (ii) comprehensive consultation with stakeholders through national workshops 
to diagnose the issues effectively, leading to adoption of relevant policies and thereby creating 
ownership;16 and (iii) formulation of the long-term national capital market master plan to ensure 
sustainability of reforms, and embed the plan within a broader government-owned long-term 
development strategy, serving as an anchor for the program.17 The program (i) pursues a focused

approach by concentrating on a few key areas, (ii) is part of a long-term engagement, and (iii) is 
integrated with government reform initiatives supported by all relevant stakeholders (footnote 16). 
 
17.  The program builds on ADB’s previous capital and financial market programs to introduce 
reform measures that deepen and broaden Pakistan’s capital markets by (i) developing the 
government yield curve and thereby promoting a more liquid government bond market through 
the  institutional  strengthening  of  the  DMO;  (ii)  enhancing  institutional  investor  demand  by 
broadening, deepening, and diversifying the investor base; (iii) strengthening the institutional and 
regulatory capacity of the SECP, the DMO, and the AOB; (iv) developing important market 
infrastructure, such as surveillance systems and a trading system for bonds; and (v) enhancing 
the supply of alternative financial instruments, such as derivatives. Government consultations 
identified the reform areas discussed in paras. 18–20. The policy matrix is in Appendix 4. 
 
18.  Market stability strengthened. The reforms will promote more robust, resilient, and 
stable capital markets through subprogram 1 actions, such as amending the Securities and 
Exchange Commission of Pakistan Act, 1997 to ensure structural changes in the appointment 
process, and commissioning operations as a collegiate body. The establishment of the National 
Finance Stability Council comprising the SBP governor, the SECP chair, and the finance minister 
(or adviser on finance and revenue)  will improve interagency policy coordination and play an 
instrumental  role  in  dealing  with systemic  issues  that cut  across  regulatory domains.  The 
introduction of a new broker model will strengthen the brokerage industry by reducing broker 
defaults. The new model will categorize brokers according to their net worth and governance 
requirements, which will ascertain appropriate operational risks to be assumed by the brokers. 
Subprogram 2 actions include exempting income tax for SECP, implementing the broker model 
and replacing legacy leverage instruments with derivatives. 
 
19.  Market facilitation enhanced. Reforms in this area will support more efficient resource 
mobilization and allocation in the economy by expediting the adjudication of enforcement actions 
and strengthening auditing standards. Expedited adjudication will complement the enhanced 
enforcement capacity at the SECP by establishing a special tribunal for capital-market-related 
cases in subprogram 1 as part of the judicial system overseen by a tribunal chair and its members. 
Subprogram 1 actions include developing  an adequately funded  AOB with a strengthened 
regulatory and operational mandate based on the adoption of international auditing standards, 
which will strengthen compliance, enhance market confidence, and allow for informed investment 
decisions. The formulation of a long-term national capital market master plan will ensure that the 
program is an integral part of a government-owned long-term development strategy. Subprogram 
2 actions include making the special tribunal operational and installing an upgraded electronic 
market surveillance system at the SECP. 
 
20.  The supply and demand of securities enhanced. This will involve supply measures in 
subprogram 1 to (i) promote alternative financial instruments through in-principle approval from 
the federal government for passage by Parliament of a netting bill to be implemented by the SECP 
and SBP that will reduce counterparty risk and the subsequent introduction of derivatives to 
develop a deeper and broader capital market, (ii) revitalize a separate PSX board for SMEs with 
reduced listing requirements and costs, and (iii) gain Cabinet approval for a streamlined taxation 
regime for nonresident companies investing in debt securities. Supply measures in subprogram

2 will (i) facilitate and expand the issuance of sovereign sukuks; (ii) partially privatize SOEs on 
the PSX to broaden and deepen the capital markets; and (iii) promote the introduction of 
alternative asset classes, such as exchange-traded funds, index and stock options, futures, and 
sharia-compliant products. Demand measures in subprogram 1 include (i) onboarding new retail 
investors through simplified KYC procedures with biometric verification, (ii) introducing volume-
based auctions with variance limits to develop a credible government yield curve, (iii) approving 
a DMO staffing plan to strengthen debt management proficiency, and (iv) developing an SECP 
policy on gender mainstreaming that will raise demand for securities through the increased 
participation of female investors since women’s participation in Pakistan’s capital markets is very 
low. Demand measures in subprogram 2 will (i) put the DMO staffing plan into operation, (ii) 
eliminate institutional investors from participating in the National Savings Scheme to promote 
contractual savings institutions and pension fund demand in the capital markets, (iii) implement a 
buyback of fragmented issues and replace them with liquid benchmark issues to create liquidity 
in the government bond market keeping in view cost risk trade off, and (iv) issue women 
entrepreneur bonds whose proceeds will facilitate the financing of SMEs owned or led by women. 
 
21.  ADB’s value addition. ADB is regarded by the government, market participants, and 
development partners as a credible party that will ensure a balanced and professional approach 
devoid of short-term interest and political interference. ADB offers an integrated approach that 
combines professional and impartial policy advice with financial support for adjustment, effective 
implementation support, and capacity development through TA to ensure sustainability. Not many 
development partners have the same level of credibility, or the means or capacity to offer this 
solutions-based approach that can effectively tailor these best practices to the needs and 
conditions of Pakistan’s capital markets by also applying ADB’s knowledge in similar programs 
across the region. Without ADB involvement in capital market reforms, and given the complexities 
involved and the resources and expertise required, such reforms would not have progressed 
successfully. 
 
22.  Development coordination. These reforms complement other initiatives, such as the 
World  Bank’s  $500  million  Resilient  Institutions  for  Sustainable  Economy  (RISE)  Program 
development  policy  financing  that  was  approved  in  June  2020,  and  the  Department  for 
International Development of the United Kingdom’s $10 million SECP Digitalization Project. The 
RISE Program will develop a legal framework for debt management, while the Department for 
International  Development  project  focuses  on  strengthening  the  SECP’s  information  and 
communication technology systems. The IMF’s $6 billion EFF program approved on 3 July 2019 
facilitates improved macroeconomic management, including through sound debt management. 
The program builds on the legal and institutional foundations of sound debt management under 
the  RISE  Program  and  the  EFF  by  developing  the  government  bond  market  through  the 
realization of a market-based government bond market yield curve. To ensure synergies and 
complementarity, ADB is closely coordinating with the IMF and other development partners. 
 
C.  Impacts of the Reform 
 
23.  The program is aligned with the following overarching development objective: capital 
markets act as a major catalyst in transforming the economy into a more efficient, innovative, and 
competitive marketplace within the global arena (footnote 4). The development of capital markets 
will  contribute  toward  achieving  this  objective  by  stimulating  competition  with  the  banking 
subsector that will lead to greater efficiencies and innovation. The program will have the following 
reform effect: the capacity and size of the capital markets are augmented. The program is 
structured around four reform areas: (i) market stability strengthened, (ii) market facilitation 
enhanced, (iii) supply measures enhanced, and (iv) demand measures enhanced. Subprogram 1

8 
reforms focus on strengthening the institutional and regulatory capacity of the SECP, the DMO, 
and the AOB, while subprogram 2 will catalyze institutional investor demand and increase the 
supply of alternative financial instruments, such as derivatives. The proposed reforms conform to 
best practices, including those promulgated by the International Organization of Securities 
Commissions. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
D.  Development Financing Needs and Budget Support 
 
24.  Based on the development financing requirements of the program, ADB will provide policy-
based loans totaling $600 million to finance two subprograms under the programmatic approach. 
The government has requested a concessional loan of $290.204 million from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources to help finance subprogram 1. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a 
grace period of 5 years; an annual interest rate of 2% per year; and such other terms and 
conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. The government has also requested a regular 
loan of $9.796 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to help finance subprogram 1. The 
loan will have a 15-year term, including a grace period of 3 years; an annual interest rate 
determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending 
facility; a commitment charge of 0.15% per year; and such other terms and conditions as set forth 
in the draft loan agreement. Based on the straight-line method, the average loan maturity is 9.25 
years, and there is no maturity premium payable to ADB. The development policy letter is in 
Appendix 3. 
 
25.  Pakistan’s development financing needs. The government’s financing requirements 
are expected to be $78.79 billion in FY2021, to be financed by domestic and foreign sources 
(Table 1). The government’s foreign borrowing will be $15.15 billion in FY2021, mainly from 
international financial institutions and bilateral partners.

26.  Debt sustainability. ADB’s debt sustainability analysis concluded that the total public 
debt–GDP ratio will reach 83.0% in FY2021 compared with 82.9% in FY2020 and 76.7% in 
FY2019. However, this ratio is expected to decline after FY2021 and stabilize at 72.6% by

9 
FY2024. External debt risks remain high, but the economy is expected to gradually recover in 
FY2021, and external debt is projected to steadily decline and return to a more sustainable path 
driven primarily by a lower current account deficit, non-debt-creating capital inflows, and higher 
economic growth in subsequent years. More importantly, the availability of adequate concessional 
financing from ADB will provide much-needed fiscal resources and allow the government to 
prioritize its development expenditure on productive investments. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
27.  The executing agency will be the MOF. The implementing agencies will be the SBP and 
the SECP. A program steering committee has been established to oversee and coordinate 
program implementation; it will also include all relevant departments of the MOF, SBP, SECP, 
and  the  PSX.  The  indicative  implementation  periods  are  June  2019–September  2020  for 
subprogram 1 and October 2020–October 2022 for subprogram 2. 
 
28.  Disbursement and counterpart funds. The loans will be provided in two subprograms 
and will be disbursed upon fulfillment of their respective program policy actions (Appendix 4). The 
proceeds  of  the  policy-based  loan  will  be  withdrawn  following  ADB’s  Loan  Disbursement 
Handbook (2017, as amended from time to time). 
 
III.  ATTACHED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
29.  The TA is estimated to cost $800,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The TA will support the implementation of key 
reform actions under the program. The major TA outputs and activities include (i) supporting 
legislative reforms such as making the capital market tribunal operational; (ii) supporting the 
discontinuation of the margin trading system and development of derivatives; (iii) facilitating the 
enhancement of market infrastructure; (iv) developing asset-light sukuk structures that involve 
intangible assets; (v) building capacity and providing training, including strengthening the Institute 
of Financial Markets; and (vi) supporting the installation of a centralized trading platform for 
primary and secondary government debt markets.18 The MOF will be the executing agency. The 
SECP and SBP will be the implementing agencies for the TA, which will be implemented over 2 
years, starting in July 2020. ADB will engage  36 person-months of individual international 
consultants and 16 person-months of individual national consultants using open competitive 
bidding following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and 
associated staff instructions. Disbursements under the TA will follow ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office, office supplies, secretarial assistance, 
and other in-kind contributions. Transaction TA of $500,000 was approved in July 2019 for the 
preparation of subprogram 1 and has been used to develop a diagnostic study and capital market 
master plan, review legislation, and draft required legislative changes. 
 
IV.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
30.  Economic and financial. The program will facilitate the mobilization of financial resources 
for productive investment, especially by the private sector, and employment generation by 
supporting the development of bond and equity capital markets. This will help reduce the cost of 
financial intermediation and help stabilize systemic vulnerabilities in the bank-dominated finance 
system. The specific transmission channels are as follows: 
 
18 Attached Technical Assistance Report (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
(i)  By addressing policy and regulatory constraints on the issuance of corporate 
securities, the program will help increase the number of bond and equity issues, 
both primary and secondary. This will facilitate the mobilization of scarce financial 
resources for long-term private sector investment. 
(ii)  By promoting the development of corporate securities markets and institutional 
investors, thereby diversifying financial instruments and broadening the investor 
base, the program will reduce market volatility and improve the resilience of the 
finance sector to external shocks. 
(iii)  By strengthening market governance in capital markets, the program will enhance 
market efficiency and transparency, and improve investor protection. 
 
31.  Governance. The governance risk assessment followed the Guidelines for Implementing 
ADB’s Second Governance and Anticorruption Action Plan.19 It found risks that could affect the 
programmatic approach, such as (i) sudden changes in administrative procedures, ministry 
leadership, and/or major staff turnover that may hinder smooth implementation of reforms cause 
delays; (ii) political support and government ownership of reforms, envisaged under the program, 
wanes; and (iii) institutional capacity is weak. While no major risks of mismanagement of 
resources at the implementing level were discerned, and Pakistan has extensive centralized 
legislative and institutional public financial management structures, budget execution remains an 
area of weakness. Institutional capacity development is targeted under the transaction TA and 
policy changes under the program. 
 
32.  Poverty and social. The capital market reforms under the program will lower the cost of 
financial intermediation and facilitate private sector investment that will lead to higher sustainable 
growth and generate job opportunities. The program also mitigates the negative impact that 
capital market instability has on the plight of the poor. It also helps Pakistan diversify its financial 
system so that the country can realize its broad-based economic growth and socioeconomic 
development objectives, including poverty reduction. The program seeks to address gender 
disparities, particularly women’s limited access to capital markets (women comprise more than 
49% of the population but only 7% of women in Pakistan have access to financial inclusion 
services).20 The program  promotes  the approval  and  implementation  of  key gender  policy 
documents at the SECP and PSX, including the legal framework for Women Entrepreneur Bonds. 
 
33.  Safeguards.  The  program  will  have  no  anticipated  direct  or  indirect  environmental 
impacts, will not cause involuntary resettlement, and will have no impacts on indigenous peoples. 
In this regard, the program is classified category C for the environment, involuntary resettlement, 
and indigenous peoples. 
 
34.  Risks and mitigating measures. The program’s risk assessment is rated moderate since 
(i) ADB has solid experience in the sector in Pakistan; (ii) the MOF, the proposed executing 
agency, has a good performance record in externally financed project implementation; and (iii) 
the program is unlikely to have any impact on safeguards. Major risks that could affect the 
program implementation and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 2 and described in 
detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.21

a  (i) adoption of a rule that a) prohibits an audit practitioner from becoming a member of AOB’s governing body in

“cooling off” period for former audit practitioners to be eligible to serve as a member of the AOB governing body 
(“Board”); (ii) ensuring that AOB should have a stable source of funding from the government, which is secured and 
free from influence by auditors and audit firms and sufficient to execute its powers and responsibilities; (iii) allowing 
for unconditional direct inspections of audit firms by AOB; (iv) making  provision requiring PICs to appoint audit firms 
registered with AOB; (v) giving AOB powers to decline registration of audit firms and/or impose conditions for
